people have been rescued from homes and vehicles in Harris County, Texas, an official said Saturday night, with evacuation orders and flood watches in place, as more rain expected descends on the state Sunday, with a bull's-eye of excessive rainfall over the already waterlogged Houston area.\n\nNo dea", "spa": "(CNN) -- Las inundaciones se est\u00e1n intensificando en Texas tras fuertes tormentas e intensas lluvias, que arrasaron con veh\u00edculos, da\u00f1aron viviendas y generaron evacuaciones.\n\nLas tormentas de esta semana fueron las \u00faltimas de una serie de fen\u00f3menos clim\u00e1ticos brutales que han azotado al estado desde principios de abril. {"uri": "2024-05-345541638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:10:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:10:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:44:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-forecast-calls-for-more-rain-and-rising-water", "title": "Hundreds Rescued From Texas Floods as Forecast Calls for More Rain and Rising Water", "body": "Houston: High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nTexas Parks & Wildlife Department game wardens use a boat to rescue residents from floodwaters in Liberty County, Texas, on Saturday, May 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nRAIN FORCES EVACUATIONS, TRAPS RESIDENTS\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nChannelview Fire Department and sheriffs get ready to help evacuate the area due to severe flooding, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Channelview, Texas. (Raquel Natalicchio/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Republic World"}, "authors": {"uri": "8111867621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:44:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:44:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:43:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2927934-texas-struggles-amidst-devastating-floods-water-levels-continue-to-surge", "title": "Texas Struggles Amidst Devastating Floods, Water Levels Continue to Surge | Science-Environment", "body": "Others prepared to evacuate their properties.A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nations third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.A lull in heavy rain is expected through Saturday evening, the National Weather Service reported.\n\nHigh waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\" Up to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county. A wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home. \"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\" RAIN FORCES EVACUATIONS, TRAPS RESIDENTS Friday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items. Water from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day. \"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING Houston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time. The greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown. The system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", {"uri": "8111796865", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:04:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:04:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:03:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/as-flood-waters-continue-rising-in-houston-hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-13767224.html", "title": "As flood waters continue rising in Houston, hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas", "body": "The bridge over Lake Houston along West Lake Houston Parkway from Kingwood to Atascocita is seen after it was closed due to high water on either side of the thoroughfare in Kingwood, Texas. AP\n\nHigh waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nResidents in low-lying areas asked to evacuate\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nOngoing rain has left parts of Texas drenched, residents trapped\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of {"uri": "8111851701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:21:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:21:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:20:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://ktar.com/story/5572509/hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-forecast-calls-for-more-rain-and-rising-water/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from Texas floods as forecast calls for more rain and rising water", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8111739458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:26:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:26:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:25:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-05-04/texas-flooding-hundreds-rescued-13755408.html", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nResidents in low-lying areas asked to evacuate\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nOngoing rain leaves parts of Texas drenched, residents trapped\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do?\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHouston one of the most flood-prone metro areas in U.S.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet. The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8111705312", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:27:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:27:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:26:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/national-international/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston/3428897/", "title": "Texas prepare for more rain in the forescast", "body": "A flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\nHigh waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops, and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters, rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 69}], "image": "https://media.nbcchicago.com/2024/05/AP24125795417643.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&resize=1200%2C675", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": "eng-9539709", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 214, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8111873675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:52:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:52:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:50:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13384117/Hundreds-rescued-Texas-floods-forecast-calls-rain-rising-water.html", "title": "Hundreds rescued from Texas floods as forecast calls for more rain...", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) - High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation\u00b4s third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County\u00b4s top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nTexas Parks & Wildlife Department game wardens use a boat to rescue residents from floodwaters in Liberty County, Texas, on Saturday, May 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\n\"It\u00b4s going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don\u00b4t know how much more. We\u00b4re just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nFriday\u00b4s fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It\u00b4s sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston\u00b4s city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week\u00b4s time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city\u00b4s growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple\u00b4s subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn\u00b4t worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn\u00b4t as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.\n\nThe Associated Press\u00b4 climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP\u00b4s standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. Lozano on X, formerly Twitter: https://twitter.com/juanlozano70\n\nTexas Parks & Wildlife Department game wardens use a boat to rescue residents from floodwaters in Liberty County, Texas, on Saturday, May 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nThe bridge over Lake Houston along West Lake Houston Parkway from Kingwood to Atascocita is seen after it was closed due to high water on either side of the thoroughfare, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Kingwood, Texas. (Jason Fochtman/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA woman, who only gave her name as Lisamarie, checks on an elderly resident inside his RV after their neighborhood was evacuated due to severe flooding, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Channelview, Texas. (Raquel Natalicchio/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA woman, who only gave her name as Lisamarie, checks on two of her puppies after her neighborhood was evacuated due to severe flooding on Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Channelview, Texas. (Raquel Natalicchio/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA man waves at Texas Parks & Wildlife Department game wardens as they arrive by boat to rescue residents from floodwaters in Liberty County, Texas, on Saturday, May 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nA stranded care is seen near the bridge over Lake Houston along West Lake Houston Parkway after it was closed due to high water on either side of the thoroughfare, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Kingwood, Texas. (Jason Fochtman/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA woman steps out of a mobile home in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Saturday afternoon, May 4, 2024. The mobile home was surrounded by flood waters caused by the nearby San Jacinto River, which was overflowing due to heavy rainfall earlier this week. (AP Photo/Juan Lozano)\n\nChannelview Fire Department and sheriffs get ready to help evacuate the area due to severe flooding, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Channelview, Texas. (Raquel Natalicchio/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nGirls ride their bikes through flood water near the bridge over Lake Houston along West Lake Houston Parkway after it was closed due to high water on either side of the thoroughfare, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Kingwood, Texas. (Jason Fochtman/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nPeople gather to walk around bridge over Lake Houston along West Lake Houston Parkway after it was closed due to high water on either side of the thoroughfare, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Kingwood, Texas (Jason Fochtman/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nChannelview Fire Department and sheriffs get ready to help evacuate the area due to severe flooding, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Channelview, Texas. (Raquel Natalicchio/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo speaks before going up in a helicopter at David Wayne Hooks Memorial Airport to survey flood damage around the northern section of greater Houston, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Spring, Texas. (Jason Fochtman/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo describes seeing power lines relative to floodwater before going up in a helicopter at David Wayne Hooks Memorial Airport to survey flood damage around the northern section of greater Houston, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Spring, Texas. {"uri": "2024-05-345252744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:16:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:16:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T18:01:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/4/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise - what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) - a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345327911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:33:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:33:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:28:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/234617/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas", "body": "HOUSTON -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\nREAD: Heavy rains in Texas close schools, flood roadways\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nREAD: Heavy rains soak Texas; downpours continue drenching parts of US\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nResidents in low-lying areas asked to evacuate\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nOngoing rain has left parts of Texas drenched, residents trapped\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345317369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:32:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:32:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:19:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-05-05/hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-forecast-calls-for-more-rain-and-rising-water", "title": "Hundreds Rescued From Texas Floods as Forecast Calls for More Rain and Rising Water", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nRAIN FORCES EVACUATIONS, TRAPS RESIDENTS\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Natural_Disasters_and_Hazards", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Natural Disasters and Hazards", "wgt": 17}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 73}], "image": "https://www.usnews.com/dims4/USNEWS/5c3d24d/2147483647/thumbnail/970x647/quality/85/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usnews.com%2Fcmsmedia%2Fc6%2F29e435847a28c9202d3d23d08190fa%2Fb9c67f124a1048e6b98541c4e0121083Severe_Weather_Texas_25316.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": "eng-9539709", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.0980392156862746, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8111618416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:07:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:07:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:07:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.wkbn.com/news/national-world/ap-houston-braces-for-flooding-to-worsen-in-wake-of-storms/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "8111882995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:04:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:04:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:03:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-forecast-calls-for-more-rain-and-rising-water-5941244.html", "title": "World News | Hundreds Rescued from Texas Floods as Forecast Calls for More Rain and Rising Water | LatestLY", "body": "Houston, May 5 (AP) High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\nAlso Read | What Is FLiRT? From Symptoms to Preventive Measures, Know All About New COVID-19 Variant Spreading Fast in US.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nAlso Read | Brazil Rains: 56 Dead, Many Missing Due to Torrential Rains and Mudslides in Rio Grande do Sul; Rescue Operations Underway.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nRAIN FORCES EVACUATIONS, TRAPS RESIDENTS\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who drove from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said flooding during Harvey reached the top of the lines.
