{"uri": "8112135288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:30:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:30:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/05/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nFloodwaters inundated a wide region Saturday, from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home. A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night to the soaked region and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\nAron Brown, 45, and his wife Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood.\n\nThe floodwaters had risen several feet and had begun to flood nearby restaurants and a gas station.\n\nThe water could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision. But Aron Brown said he wasn't worried as his home was at a higher elevation than other ones in their subdivision.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nResidents in low-lying areas asked to evacuate\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into (today).\"\n\nUp to 3 inches of additional rain is expected with up to 5 inches more possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said Saturday the area is expecting more rain today and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nOngoing rain leaves parts of state drenched\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2\u00bd acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items before flood waters inundated his home.\n\nWaters from the nearby San Jacinto River had swallowed his backyard and continued to rise Saturday.\n\nFlores said the water in his backyard was only about 1 foot high on Friday. On Saturday, the water level measured about 4 feet.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do?\" Flores asked, adding that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, where high waters reached the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches of rain fell during the five-day period that ended Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people have been rescued and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, located about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they have done more than 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHouston one of most flood-prone metro areas in U.S.\n\nAuthorities in Houston had not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has lots of experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall on the area, flooding thousands of homes and resulting in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River in the northeastern part of Harris County, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release extra water from an already full reservoir. Hidalgo on Thursday issued a mandatory evacuation order for those living along portions of the river.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area had about four months of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was nearly 74 feet late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet. The rapidly changing forecast said the river is expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet by Thursday.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles to the southeast from downtown.\n\nThe city's system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains. But engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nJoseph Torres stands in the remains of his father's home in Hodges, Texas, Friday May 3, 2024. It and several other houses in the unincorporated Jones County community west of Hawley were damaged or destroyed by a tornado Thursday evening. (Ronald W. Erdrich/The Abilene Reporter-News via AP)\n\nConroe firefighter Cody Leroy carries a resident evacuated in a boat by the CFD Rapid Intervention Team from her flooded home in the aftermath of a severe storm, Thursday, May 2, 2024, in Conroe, Texas. Torrential rain is inundating southeastern Texas, forcing schools to cancel classes and closing numerous highways around Houston. {"uri": "2024-05-345237009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:37:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:37:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:36:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/flooding-texas-houston-rescues/60691580", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston", "body": "High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.Floodwaters inundated a wide region Saturday, from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home. A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night to the soaked region and the likelihood of major flooding.\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" Miguel Flores Jr. of Kingwood said. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"Aron Brown, 45, and his wife Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood.The floodwaters had risen several feet and had begun to flood nearby restaurants and a gas station.The water could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision. But Aron Brown said he wasn't worried as his home was at a higher elevation than other ones in their subdivision.Brown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.Residents in low-lying areas asked to evacuateFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"Up to 3 inches of additional rain is expected with up to 5 inches more possible in isolated areas.Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said Saturday that the area is expecting more rain on Sunday and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.Ongoing rain has left parts of Texas drenched, residents trappedMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2 1/2 acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items before flood waters inundated his home.Waters from the nearby San Jacinto River had swallowed his backyard and continued to rise on Saturday.Flores said the water in his backyard was only about 1 foot high on Friday. On Saturday, the water level now measured about 4 feet.\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.For weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, where high waters reached the roofs of some homes.More than 21 inches of rain fell during the five-day period that ended Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.Hidalgo said Saturday that 178 people have been rescued and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, located about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.Houston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the USAuthorities in Houston had not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall on the area, flooding thousands of homes and resulting in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.Of particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River in the northeastern part of Harris County, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release extra water from an already full reservoir. Hidalgo on Thursday issued a mandatory evacuation order for those living along portions of the river.Most of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area had about four months of rain in about a week's time.The weather service reported the river was nearly 74 feet late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet. The rapidly changing forecast said the river is expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet by Thursday.The greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles to the southeast from downtown.The city's system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains. But engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms. ___Associated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, and Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\nHigh waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nFloodwaters inundated a wide region Saturday, from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home. A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night to the soaked region and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" Miguel Flores Jr. of Kingwood said. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nAron Brown, 45, and his wife Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood.\n\nThe floodwaters had risen several feet and had begun to flood nearby restaurants and a gas station.\n\nThe water could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision. But Aron Brown said he wasn't worried as his home was at a higher elevation than other ones in their subdivision.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nResidents in low-lying areas asked to evacuate\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches of additional rain is expected with up to 5 inches more possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said Saturday that the area is expecting more rain on Sunday and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nOngoing rain has left parts of Texas drenched, residents trapped\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2 1/2 acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items before flood waters inundated his home.\n\nWaters from the nearby San Jacinto River had swallowed his backyard and continued to rise on Saturday.\n\nFlores said the water in his backyard was only about 1 foot high on Friday. On Saturday, the water level now measured about 4 feet.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, where high waters reached the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches of rain fell during the five-day period that ended Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people have been rescued and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, located about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the US\n\nAuthorities in Houston had not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall on the area, flooding thousands of homes and resulting in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River in the northeastern part of Harris County, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release extra water from an already full reservoir. Hidalgo on Thursday issued a mandatory evacuation order for those living along portions of the river.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area had about four months of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was nearly 74 feet late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet. The rapidly changing forecast said the river is expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet by Thursday.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles to the southeast from downtown.\n\nThe city's system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains. But engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "kmbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KMBC "https://kubrick.htvapps.com/htv-prod-media.s3.amazonaws.com/images/gettyimages-2151304283-6636aa260a44a.jpg?crop=1.00xw:0.848xh;0,0&resize=640:*", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": "eng-9539709", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8112106431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:03:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:03:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:01:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/05/heavy-rains-lead-to-flooding-in-houston/", "title": "Heavy rains lead to flooding in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said that more rain was expected Sunday, and that if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do?\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads last week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they had done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nPhoto GalleryHeavy rains lead to flooding in Houston\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet. The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet by Thursday.\n\nMost within Houston's city limits were not heavily affected by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Ken Miller, Jim Vertuno and Valerie Gonzalez of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "arkansasonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArkansasOnline"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111680547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:48:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:48:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:47:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.vaildaily.com/news/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.", "source": {"uri": "vaildaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8111843193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:11:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:11:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:09:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston_990579.html", "title": "Hundreds Rescued From Flooding in Texas as Waters Continue Rising in Houston", "body": "HOUSTON -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nRESIDENTS IN LOW-LYING AREAS ASKED TO EVACUATE\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nONGOING RAIN HAS LEFT PARTS OF TEXAS DRENCHED, RESIDENTS TRAPPED\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHOUSTON IS ONE OF THE MOST FLOOD-PRONE METRO AREAS IN THE US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": "news/Politics", "wgt": 69}], "image": "https://i.ntd.com/assets/uploads/2024/05/id990580-Houston.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": "eng-9539709", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8111739525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "01:26:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T01:26:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T01:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston/", "title": "Hundreds Rescued From Flooding In Texas As Waters Continue Rising In Houston", "body": "A man walks through floodwaters on River Oaks Drive, Saturday, May 4, 2024, in Woodlock, Texas. (/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nBy JUAN A. LOZANO and LEKAN OYEKANMI Associated Press\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nRESIDENTS IN LOW-LYING AREAS ASKED TO EVACUATE\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nONGOING RAIN HAS LEFT PARTS OF TEXAS DRENCHED, RESIDENTS TRAPPED\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHOUSTON IS ONE OF THE MOST FLOOD-PRONE METRO AREAS IN THE US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "8111638907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:39:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2024-05-04/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-water-continue-rising-in-houston", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as water continues rising in Houston", "body": "High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through [Saturday] evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about a foot high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches fell over five days through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles northeast of Houston, officials said they have made more than 100 water rescues in the last few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted, though officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week.", "source": {"uri": "latimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Los Angeles Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111816614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:31:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continue rising in Houston | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nRESIDENTS IN LOW-LYING AREAS ASKED TO EVACUATE\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nONGOING RAIN HAS LEFT PARTS OF TEXAS DRENCHED, RESIDENTS TRAPPED\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHOUSTON IS ONE OF THE MOST FLOOD-PRONE METRO AREAS IN THE US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Ken Miller in Edmond, Oklahoma, Jim Vertuno in Austin, and Valerie Gonzalez in McAllen, Texas, contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "8114146324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:36:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.claimsjournal.com/news/southcentral/2024/05/06/323449.htm", "title": "Hundreds Rescued From Flooded Neighborhoods From Houston to East Texas", "body": "High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nRESIDENTS IN LOW-LYING AREAS ASKED TO EVACUATE\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nONGOING RAIN HAS LEFT PARTS OF TEXAS DRENCHED, RESIDENTS TRAPPED\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise -- what was about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday measured about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nHOUSTON IS ONE OF THE MOST FLOOD-PRONE METRO AREAS IN THE US\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported that the river was at nearly 74 feet (22.6 meters) late Saturday morning after reaching nearly 78 feet (23.7 meters). The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near flood stage of 58 feet (17.6 meters) by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers) -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Others prepared to evacuate their property.A wide region was swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.A flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., of the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"Husband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighborhood.Brown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nRESIDENTS IN LOW-LYING AREAS ASKED TO EVACUATE\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. {"uri": "8113078997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:39:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:39:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:38:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/485922/As-storms-move-across-Texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press A heron stands as water flows over N. Houston Road, making the road impassible on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Humble, Texas. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nStorms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345835454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:39:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:39:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:33:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2024/05/05/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floods/73579556007/", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floods", "body": "Houston - More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFlooding forces evacuations\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston prone to flooding\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWhat's expected next\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-346110366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:22:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:22:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:37:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/", "title": "As Storms Moves Across Texas, 1 Child Dies after Being Swept Away in Floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of {"uri": "8114191184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:12:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:12:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:12:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-05-06/heavy-rains-flooding-texas-13769900.html", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches to almost 17 inches of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nChild dies in floodwaters\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHouston-area river levels\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nStengle reported from Dallas, and Associated Press reporter Juan A.
