{"uri": "8111719228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:51:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:51:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:49:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/hundreds-rescued-from-flooding-in-texas-as-waters-continue-rising-in-houston/VEV7XPR775CVJJZPN5Y6NVIJ6E/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from flooding in Texas as waters keep rising", "body": "High waters flooded neighbourhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that have already resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nA wide region was swamped from Houston to rural east Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\nA flood watch was in effect through Sunday afternoon, as forecasters predicted additional rainfall on Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr, of the northeast Houston neighbourhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWater could be seen flowing into parts of the couple's subdivision, but Aron Brown said he wasn't worried because their home is at a higher elevation than others in the neighbourhood.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as that caused by Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said floodwater levels during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through [Saturday] evening,\" according to the National Weather Service. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late [on Saturday] into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 7.6cm of additional rain was expected, with up to 12.7cm possible in isolated areas.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said more rain was expected on Sunday, and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr is mowing his huge backyard on a 1ha lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River had already swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise - what was about 30cm high in the yard on Friday measured about 1.2m the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do?\" Flores said. He added he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 53cm fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 350km northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said on Saturday 178 people and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighbouring Montgomery County. In Polk County, about 160km northeast of Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\nAuthorities in Houston have not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than two million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has much experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release water from a full reservoir. Hidalgo issued a mandatory evacuation order on Thursday for people living along portions of the river.\n\nThe weather service reported the river was at nearly 22.6m late on Saturday morning after reaching nearly 23.7m. The rapidly changing forecast said the river was expected to fall to near the flood stage of 17.6m by Thursday.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather. Officials said the area received about four months' worth of rain in about a week's time.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 25,900 square kilometres - a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is criss-crossed by about 2700km of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 80km southeast of the downtown area.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering system initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", {"uri": "8112959569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:55:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:55:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:54:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/5/6/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112596787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:00:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:00:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:59:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2928390-unrelenting-rains-pummel-houston-leaving-hundreds-stranded-in-floodwaters", "title": "Unrelenting Rains Pummel Houston, Leaving Hundreds Stranded in Floodwaters | Science-Environment", "body": "Heavy rains in Houston have caused flooding, leading to hundreds of rescues. The National Weather Service warns of more storms and up to 8 inches of additional rainfall, prompting evacuations. Authorities have not reported any casualties. Despite being a flood-prone area, Houston's infrastructure struggles to handle the city's growth and intense storms. Residents are urged to prepare for rising waters and subsequent heat and humidity after the rain subsides.\n\nMore storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\" Houston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day. As storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday. \"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\" He moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown. The system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, {"uri": "8112616457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:20:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:20:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:19:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-more-storms-move-through-houston-area", "title": "Hundreds rescued from Texas floods as more storms move through Houston area", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\nREAD MORE: As 'flash floods are getting flashier,' communities worry about aging infrastructure\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFlooding forces evacuations\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston prone to flooding\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nREAD MORE: Why Hurricane Harvey became so extreme\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWhat's expected next\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nAssociated Press reporter Jamie Stengle in Dallas contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "lekan_oyekanmi@pbs.org", "name": "Lekan Oyekanmi", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@pbs.org", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8113057417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:12:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:12:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:12:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/as-storms-move-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8112824262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:35:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:35:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:32:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/article_e4144672-d648-5857-a418-f9c7f64c8cff.html", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "A mobile home in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Sunday morning, May 5, 2024, is surrounded by flood waters caused by the nearby San Jacinto River, which overflowed due to heavy rainfall earlier this week.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches (8 centimeters) of rainfall, with up to 8 inches (20 centimeters) possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-345927896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:00:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:00:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:35:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://wgntv.com/news/national/ap-hundreds-rescued-from-texas-floods-as-forecast-calls-for-more-rain-and-rising-water/", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8112709064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:02:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:02:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-05-05/houston-storms-flooding-13760857.html", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFlooding forces evacuations\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston prone to flooding\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWhat's expected next\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F, the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. "https://www.stripes.com/incoming/5paav1-5-5-24-houston-flood-ap.jpg/alternates/LANDSCAPE_480/5-5-24%20houston%20flood%20ap.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": {"uri": "2024-05-345966769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:55:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:55:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:47:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/as-storms-move-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/article_aca49496-2446-52db-8fdc-4048ec7cac4a.html", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nStengle contributed to this report from Dallas. Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano also contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "2024-05-345917894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:34:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:34:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:30:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/nation-world/child-dies-in-floodwaters-as-storms-intensify-across-texas-houston-rainfall-flooding-forth-worth-lake-livingston-severe-weather-wx-storms-emergency-response-water-rescues", "title": "Child dies in floodwaters as storms intensify across Texas", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches (8 centimeters) of rainfall, with up to 8 inches (20 centimeters) possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\nIt's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. {"uri": "8112605299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:07:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters-5942769.html", "title": "World News | More Storms Move Through Houston Area, Where Hundreds Have Been Rescued from Floodwaters | LatestLY", "body": "Houston, May 5 (AP) More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nAlso Read | Al Jazeera Offices To Shut In Israel: 'Incitement Channel' Al Jazeera Will No Longer Broadcast From Country, Says Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\nAlso Read | US: Driver Dies After Speeding Vehicle Crashes Into Security Barrier Around White House Complex, Say Authorities (Watch Video).\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said. {"uri": "2024-05-345762206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:33:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:33:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:13:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters/article_aca49496-2446-52db-8fdc-4048ec7cac4a.html", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFLOODING FORCES EVACUATIONS\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nAssociated Press reporter Jamie Stengle in Dallas contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "8112829784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:40:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:40:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:40:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://triblive.com/news/world/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nChild dies in floodwaters\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHouston-area river levels\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain {"uri": "8112852128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "22:12:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T22:12:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:12:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters-as-storms-moves/", "title": "Child dies after being swept away in floodwaters as storms moves across Texas", "body": "Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was travelling in got stuck in flood waters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimetres) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimetres) to almost 17 inches (43 centimetres) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches (23 centimetres) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbour's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the flood waters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometres), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is criss-crossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometres) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometres) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8112808861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:10:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:10:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:09:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/article_d50d96a1-b676-53af-b11a-82f847731bc9.html", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches (8 centimeters) of rainfall, with up to 8 inches (20 centimeters) possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nStengle contributed to this report from Dallas. Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano also contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A.
