{"uri": "2024-05-345917030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:02:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/article_aca49496-2446-52db-8fdc-4048ec7cac4a.html", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches (8 centimeters) of rainfall, with up to 8 inches (20 centimeters) possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nStengle contributed to this report from Dallas. Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano also contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9539709", "eventUri": "eng-9539709", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.003921568627450966, "wgt": 192, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8111605812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:51:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:51:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:51:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/texas/news/houston-texas-storms-flooding-weather-warnings/", "title": "Hundreds rescued from floodwaters around Houston as millions in Texas, Oklahoma, remain under threat", "body": "Crews rescued more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water in Texas following heavy rains on Saturday. Others prepared to evacuate their property.\n\nFloodwaters inundated a wide region Saturday, from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters and rescued both people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home. A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night to the soaked region and the likelihood of major flooding. About 11 million people in Texas and Oklahoma are under flood warnings and watches this weekend.\n\nFriday's storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. One such incident was caught on camera, as someone filmed a large truck being swept away as its driver jumped from the cab. The driver was later rescued.\n\nOfficials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo said Saturday that the area is expecting more rain on Sunday and if it's a lot, it could be problematic. Hidalgo is the top elected official in the nation's third-largest county.\n\nMore than 21 inches of rain fell during the five-day period that ended Friday in Liberty County near Splendora, a city about 30 miles northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nHidalgo said Saturday that 178 people have been rescued and 122 pets have been rescued so far in the county. Scores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery County. In Polk County, located about 100 miles from Houston, officials said they have done over 100 water rescues in the past few days.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service said. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nAron Brown, 45, and his wife Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood.\n\nThe floodwaters had risen several feet and had begun to flood nearby restaurants and a gas station.\n\nBrown, who had driven from his home in a golf cart, said the flooding wasn't as bad as Hurricane Harvey in 2017. He pointed to nearby power lines and said that flooding during Harvey had reached the top of the lines.\n\nMost weekends, Miguel Flores Sr. is mowing his huge backyard on a 2 1/2 acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family were loading several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items before flood waters inundated his home.\n\nWaters from the nearby San Jacinto River had swallowed his backyard and continued to rise on Saturday.\n\nFlores said the water in his backyard was only about 1 foot high on Friday. On Saturday, the water level now measured about 4 feet.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said. He added that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, where high waters reached the roofs of some homes. Hundreds of structures are flooded, and more are dealing with power outages.\n\nIn the rural community of Shepherd, Gilroy Fernandes said he and his spouse had about an hour to evacuate after a mandatory order. Their home is on stilts near the Trinity River, and they felt relief when the water began to recede on Thursday.\n\nThen the danger grew while they slept.\n\n\"Next thing you know, overnight they started releasing more water from the dam at Livingston. And so that caused the level of the river to shoot up by almost 5 or 6 feet overnight,\" Fernandes said. Neighbors who left an hour later got stuck in traffic because of flooding.\n\nIn Montgomery County, Judge Mark Keough said there had been more high-water rescues than he was able to count.\n\n\"We estimate we've had a couple hundred rescues from homes, from houses, from vehicles,\" Keough said.\n\nShe said homes below Lake Livingston Dam and along the Trinity River have flooded.\n\n\"It'll be when things subside before we can do our damage assessment,\" Comstock said.\n\nThe U.S. Coast Guard said they evacuated via helicopter an hours-old baby from Cleveland, Texas amid the floodwaters. The baby, who was just 12 hours old, was reportedly experiencing low oxygen levels at Texas Emergency Hospital. The hospital does not have a neonatal intensive care unit, and flooding made it impossible to transport the baby to another facility via ambulance. The helicopter crew transported the baby, mother and a paramedic to Texas Children's Hospital in Houston. The baby is in stable condition, the Coast Guard said.\n\nAuthorities in Houston had not reported any deaths or injuries. The city of more than 2 million people is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country and has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall on the area, flooding thousands of homes and resulting in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nOf particular concern was an area along the San Jacinto River in the northeastern part of Harris County, which was expected to continue rising as more rain falls and officials release extra water from an already full reservoir. Judge Hidalgo on Thursday issued a mandatory evacuation order for those living along portions of the river.\n\nMost of Houston's city limits were not heavily impacted by the weather, except for the northeastern neighborhood of Kingwood. Officials said the area had about four months of rain in about a week's time. Houston Mayor John Whitmire said rising flood waters from the San Jacinto River were expected to impact Kingwood late Friday and Saturday.\n\nShelters have opened across the region, including nine by the American Red Cross.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles -- a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous that drain into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles to the southeast from downtown.\n\nThe city's system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains. But engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nResidents in rural central and west Texas are also working to recover from tornadoes that left a trail of damage. In Hawley, Texas, two people were hurt Thursday, and the twisters left a trail of damage. This weekend's storms pose the threat of more tornadoes.\n\nTexas isn't the only area facing severe weather this weekend. Americans from Louisiana to Oregon are under the threat of severe, slow-moving storms. In Oregon's Cascades region, a winter weather warning was issued as the region braces for at least a foot of snow, according to local media.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris canceled a planned trip to a music festival in Las Vegas, Nevada after the event was canceled due to a high wind warning. Organizers said they are expecting winds between 30 and 35 miles per hour, with gusts of up to 60 miles per hour.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, {"uri": "8112616843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:20:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:20:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:19:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2024-05-05/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upward of 20 inches of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFLOODING FORCES EVACUATIONS\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 degrees Fahrenheit, the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" {"uri": "8112808018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:09:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:09:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:08:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-hundreds-already-rescued-from-floodwaters/7598859.html", "title": "More storms move through Houston area; hundreds already rescued from floodwaters", "body": "More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 50 centimeters of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 30 centimeters of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 8 centimeters of rainfall, with up to 20 centimeters possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFlooding forces evacuations\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 1-hectare lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 30 centimeters high in the yard Friday to about 1.2 meters the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several centimeters of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston prone to flooding\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the United States. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 25,900 square kilometers, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 2,700 kilometers of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 80 kilometers southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWhat's expected next\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 32 C, the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.", {"uri": "8113513739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:34:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:34:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T09:34:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/06/as-storms-move-across-texas-1-child-dies-after/", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nThrough last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nThrough the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nA mobile home in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Sunday morning, May 5, 2024, is surrounded by flood waters caused by the nearby San Jacinto River, which overflowed due to heavy rainfall earlier this week. {"uri": "2024-05-346308236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:03:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:03:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/texas-floods-may/60697886", "title": "1 child dies after being swept away in Texas floodwaters", "body": "Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.Over the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches to almost 17 inches of rain in that same period.Scattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.He said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.CHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERSIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.The child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.The two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.Storms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.HOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELSOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.Jeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.Lindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.Greg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"Moss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.HOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODINGHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.The greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.The system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nStorms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches to almost 17 inches of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain {"uri": "8114251306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:03:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:03:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:02:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/floodwaters-start-receding-around-houston-area-as-recovery-begins-following-rescues-and-evacuations/", "title": "Floodwaters Start Receding Around Houston Area As Recovery Begins Following Rescues And Evacuations", "body": "(AP) -- Floodwaters in the Houston area began to recede on Monday, allowing residents to begin returning to their homes and assess damages after days of heavy rainfall that pummeled the area and led to hundreds of rescues -- including people who were stranded on rooftops.\n\nOfficials in Harris County, where Houston is located, reported no deaths or major injuries from the flooding. But in North Texas, a 4-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAfter days of heavy rainfall in the Houston area and other parts of Southeast Texas, the forecast on Monday called for mainly sunny skies with a slight chance of showers.\n\n\"We can absolutely see the light at the end of the tunnel, and we've made it through the worst of this weather event,\" Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo, the county's top elected official, told reporters Monday.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said. Areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county, had a range of between 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nHidalgo said 233 people and 186 pets had been rescued in Harris County over the last few days. Active rescues stopped Monday, and officials were transitioning from a response phase into recovery mode and cleanup, she said.\n\nWhile many of the impacted neighborhoods and subdivisions along the San Jacinto River in Harris County were accessible on Monday, others remained cut off by flooded roadways.\n\nOfficials were still assessing how many homes were damaged.\n\n\"We're a resilient community. I know we'll continue to recover from this,\" said Harris County Sheriff Ed Gonzalez.\n\nAt least five school districts around the Houston area were closed on Monday due to the flooding.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nMost of the city of Houston was not heavily impacted by last week's rainfall, except for the neighborhood of Kingwood, where some homes and roads flooded.\n\nVarious counties and communities north and east of the Houston area also continued to recover on Monday.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs were around him.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said. The Tarrant County medical examiner's office said the cause of death of the child, who would have turned 5 later this month, was drowning.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporter Jamie Stengle in Dallas and videojournalist Lekan Oyekanmi in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "kurv.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-346311064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:05:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:05:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T23:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/as-storms-move-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters-1.6874483", "title": "As storms move across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was travelling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimetres) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of six inches (15 centimetres) to almost 17 inches (43 centimetres) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Fowler said.\n\nHe said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nChild dies in floodwaters\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a five-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as nine inches (23 centimetres) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHouston-area river levels\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from one foot (0.30 metres) to three feet (0.91 metres) overnight, he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbour's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometres), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometres) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometres) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n------\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-345926989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:58:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:58:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:02:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/article_c20d76f4-6da3-5ffc-af3c-a113194430fb.html", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, 1 child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches (8 centimeters) of rainfall, with up to 8 inches (20 centimeters) possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nCHILD DIES IN FLOODWATERS\n\nIn Johnson County, located south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nHOUSTON-AREA RIVER LEVELS\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8114237364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:50:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:50:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/floodwaters-start-receding-around-houston-area-as-recovery-begins-following-rescues-and-evacuations/article_d50d96a1-b676-53af-b11a-82f847731bc9.html", "title": "Floodwaters start receding around Houston area as recovery begins following rescues and evacuations", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Floodwaters in the Houston area began to recede on Monday, allowing residents to begin returning to their homes and assess damages after days of heavy rainfall that pummeled the area and led to hundreds of rescues -- including people who were stranded on rooftops.\n\nOfficials in Harris County, where Houston is located, reported no deaths or major injuries from the flooding. But in North Texas, a 4-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAfter days of heavy rainfall in the Houston area and other parts of Southeast Texas, the forecast on Monday called for mainly sunny skies with a slight chance of showers.\n\n\"We can absolutely see the light at the end of the tunnel, and we've made it through the worst of this weather event,\" Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo, the county's top elected official, told reporters Monday.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said. Areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county, had a range of between 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nHidalgo said 233 people and 186 pets had been rescued in Harris County over the last few days. Active rescues stopped Monday, and officials were transitioning from a response phase into recovery mode and cleanup, she said.\n\nWhile many of the impacted neighborhoods and subdivisions along the San Jacinto River in Harris County were accessible on Monday, others remained cut off by flooded roadways.\n\nOfficials were still assessing how many homes were damaged.\n\n\"We're a resilient community. I know we'll continue to recover from this,\" said Harris County Sheriff Ed Gonzalez.\n\nAt least five school districts around the Houston area were closed on Monday due to the flooding.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nMost of the city of Houston was not heavily impacted by last week's rainfall, except for the neighborhood of Kingwood, where some homes and roads flooded.\n\nVarious counties and communities north and east of the Houston area also continued to recover on Monday.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs were around him.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said. The Tarrant County medical examiner's office said the cause of death of the child, who would have turned 5 later this month, was drowning.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nAssociated Press reporter Jamie Stengle in Dallas and videojournalist Lekan Oyekanmi in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nFollow Juan A. {"uri": "2024-05-345761672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:32:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:32:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:13:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters/article_c20d76f4-6da3-5ffc-af3c-a113194430fb.html", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFLOODING FORCES EVACUATIONS\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8112827884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "21:38:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T21:38:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T21:37:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2024/05/05/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters/", "title": "As storms moves across Texas, a child dies after being swept away in floodwaters", "body": "By JAMIE STENGLE and LEKAN OYEKANMI (Associated Press)\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area, where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads. To the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, northeast of Houston, have gotten upward of 20 inches of rain, said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams. Meanwhile, she said, as much as 12 inches of rain has fallen in northeastern Harris County, which includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to an additional 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas before tapering off in the evening.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" Adams said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Moore said.\n\nStorms brought as 9 inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to Dallas-Fort Worth overnight, said National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. Stalley said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nOver the last few days, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot to 3 feet overnight. he said.\n\nLindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\n\"It'll be OK to go in there in the morning,\" he said.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe Houston area's system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8113006860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:06:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:06:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:05:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/as-storms-moves-across-texas-1-child-dies-after-being-swept-away-in-floodwaters-5644221", "title": "As Storms Moves Across Texas, 1 Child Dies After Being Swept Away in Floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON -- Storms in Texas brought additional rain Sunday to the already saturated Houston area where hundreds of people have been rescued from flooded homes and roads, while to the north in the Fort Worth area, a child died after being swept away when the car he was traveling in got stuck in floodwaters.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday afternoon. Meanwhile, he said, areas in northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston, had a range of 6 inches (15 centimeters) to almost 17 inches (43 centimeters) of rain in that same period.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said.\n\n\"With the rainfall that fell overnight plus this morning it just kind of prolonged the river flooding that we were experiencing,\" Mr. Fowler said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to get to dry ground when they were swept away, Jamie Moore, the Johnson County Emergency Management director, wrote in a Facebook post.\n\nThe two adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Mr. Moore said.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said Sunday afternoon that \"things are improving slowly.\"\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" said Mr. Lindner. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, with its east and west forks and main stem below Lake Houston falling from 1 foot (0.30 meters) to 3 feet (0.91 meters) overnight. he said.\n\nMr. Lindner said that so far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding. He urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas are still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Mr. Lindner said.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, was staying put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. On Saturday, he packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where planned to stay until the waters recede. He said Sunday that the floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and that he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks, and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.", "source": {"uri": Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of suburban Houston, school officials in Channelview cancelled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said on Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighbourhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nJeff Lindner, a meteorologist with the Harris County Flood Control District, said on Sunday \"things are improving slowly\".\n\nHarris is the US's third-largest county and includes Houston.\n\n\"We have water going down on our river systems,\" Mr Lindner said. He said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nStorms brought as nine inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nIn Brazil, floods in southern Rio Grande do Sul state had killed at least 75 people in the past seven days, and another 103 were reported missing, local authorities said on Sunday.\n\nAt least 155 people were injured, while damage from the rains forced more than 88,000 people from their homes. {"uri": "8112562135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:22:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:22:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:22:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/05/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters/", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "A man walks through floodwaters on River Oaks Drive on Saturday in Woodloch, Texas. Karen Warren/Houston Chronicle via Associated Press\n\nHOUSTON -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nRelated Houston braces for flooding to worsen in wake of storms\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFLOODING FORCES EVACUATIONS\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles, a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles southeast of downtown.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F, the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said. The Tarrant County medical examiner's office said the cause of death of the child, who would have turned 5 later this month, was drowning.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede.
