{"uri": "8112643508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "17:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T17:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T17:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas/2024/05/05/more-rain-headed-for-swamped-houston/", "title": "More rain headed for swamped Houston", "body": "HOUSTON -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nBreaking News\n\nGet the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's on higher ground.\n\nHOUSTON PRONE TO FLOODING\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nHurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris County.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe greater Houston area covers about 10,000 square miles (25,900 square kilometers), a footprint slightly bigger than New Jersey. It is crisscrossed by about 1,700 miles (2,700 kilometers) of channels, creeks and bayous draining into the Gulf of Mexico, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) southeast of downtown.\n\nThe system of bayous and reservoirs was built to drain heavy rains, but the engineering initially designed nearly 100 years ago has struggled to keep up with the city's growth and bigger storms.\n\nHusband and wife Aron Brown, 45, and Jamie Brown, 41, were two of the many residents who drove or walked to watch the rising waters near a flooded intersection close to the San Jacinto River. Nearby restaurants and a gas station were beginning to flood.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she said.\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreFlash floods sweep across Texas, killing 5-year-old in Johnson CountyLetters to the Editor - Jewish state, antisemitism, media awards, the Tony AwardsLetters to the Editor -- The blurry lines between free speech and campus safetyHouston flooding with more rain to come\n\nBy JUAN A. {"uri": "8114188209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:10:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:10:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:09:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.denver7.com/weather/heavy-rains-ease-around-houston-but-flooding-remains-after-hundreds-of-rescues-and-evacuations", "title": "Heavy rains ease around Houston but flooding remains after hundreds of rescues and evacuations", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were stranded on rooftops.\n\nA 4-year-old boy died fter being swept away in fast waters after the car he was riding in got stuck, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said. The Tarrant County medical examiner's office said the cause of death of the child, who would have turned 5 later this month, was drowning.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\n___\n\nThis story corrects the age of the young boy who died to 4 instead of 5.\n\n___\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8113144412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:49:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:49:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:47:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/houston-texas-flooding-severe-weather-o72568", "title": "Heavy rains ease around Houston but flooding remains after hundreds of rescues and evacuations", "body": "HOUSTON -- Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were standed on rooftops.\n\nA 5-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\n___\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. {"uri": "8112365794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:07:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:07:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:07:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/may/05/texas-houston-flooding", "title": "At least 400 rescued from flooding in Texas as waters continues rising", "body": "A flood watch remains in effect through Sunday afternoon after forecasters predict additional rainfall in Harris county\n\nHigh waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon after forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris county, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris county's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. One crew brought a family and three dogs aboard as rising waters surrounded their cars and home.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr, of the north-east Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nFriday's fierce storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes. Officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr, is mowing his huge back yard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1ft (30cm) high in the yard Friday to about 4ft (1.2m the following day.\n\n\"It's sad, but what can I do,\" Flores said, noting that he has flood insurance.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Flood waters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21in (53cm) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty county near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50km) north-east of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nScores of rescues took place in neighboring Montgomery county. In Polk county, about 100 miles (160km) north-east of Houston, officials said there had been more than 100 water rescues in the previous few days.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. The city of more than 2 million people has long experience dealing with devastating weather.\n\nMany in and around Houston have said the weekend's flooding is the worst since Hurricane Harvey, which in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues by government rescue personnel across Harris county.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-345542572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:11:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:11:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:10:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.bna.bh/en/HundredsrescuedfromTexasfloodsasforecastcallsformorerainandrisingwater.aspx?cms=q8FmFJgiscL2fwIzON1%2BDoAqGJ4fKKFkrkssiSeb%2FZw%3D", "title": "Hundreds rescued from Texas floods as forecast calls for more rain and rising water", "body": "Houston, May 5 (BNA): High waters flooded neighborhoods around Houston on Saturday following heavy rains that resulted in crews rescuing more than 400 people from homes, rooftops and roads engulfed in murky water. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas, the Associated Press (AP) reported.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nFor weeks, drenching rains in Texas and parts of Louisiana have filled reservoirs and saturated the ground. Floodwaters partially submerged cars and roads this week across parts of southeastern Texas, north of Houston, reaching the roofs of some homes.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimeters) fell over a five-day period through Friday in Liberty County near the city of Splendora, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northeast of Houston, according to the National Weather Service.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345957615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:54:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:54:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2024-05-06/heavy-rains-ease-around-houston-but-flooding-remains-after-hundreds-of-rescues-and-evacuations", "title": "Heavy Rains Ease Around Houston but Flooding Remains After Hundreds of Rescues and Evacuations", "body": "Alvaro Trevino pulls a canoe with Jennifer Tellez and Ailyn, 8, after they checked on their home on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Spendora, Texas. The family has lived on the property in a rental trailer for two years. \"It's really bad,\" said Tellez, who says they stayed dry during the most recent flooding in February. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were standed on rooftops.\n\nA 5-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\n___\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. {"uri": "8112154822", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:47:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:47:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.mangalorean.com/over-600-rescued-from-flooded-areas-in-texas/", "title": "Over 600 rescued from flooded areas in Texas - Mangalorean.com", "body": "Over 600 rescued from flooded areas in Texas\n\nHouston: More than 600 people have been rescued from flooded areas around Houston, the fourth largest US city, as a flood watch continues through Sunday afternoon in eastern Texas.\n\nMore rainfall was forecast, raising the risk of major flooding.\n\n\"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday,\" the National Weather Service posted on social media, Xinhua news agency reported.\n\nMore than 21 inches (53 centimetres) of rain fell in the past five days near Splendora, about 30 miles (50 km) northeast of Houston, said the service.\n\nLina Hidalgo, judge of Harris County, said at a news conference on Saturday that nearly 180 people and 122 pets had been rescued from murky water across multiple areas in the county.\n\nLocal media reported more than 100 water rescues in Polk County and nearly 400 in Montgomery County. All three counties are in or around the Houston metro area.\n\nThe water rose nearly as high as the power lines close to the East Fork of the San Jacinto. Other areas had water up to rooftops, the Houston Chronicle reported on Saturday. Hidalgo described the flooding along the East Fork as the \"worst one since Harvey.\"\n\nHidalgo on Thursday ordered a mandatory evacuation of the Houston areas along the east fork of the San Jacinto River, asking residents to leave their homes as soon as possible.\n\nHouston city officials said on Saturday that the area received about four months' worth of rain in about one week. {"uri": "2024-05-346351189", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:40:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:40:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/heavy-rains-ease-around-houston-but-flooding-remains-after-hundreds-of-rescues-and-evacuations/", "title": "Heavy Rains Ease Around Houston But Flooding Remains after Hundreds of Rescues and Evacuations", "body": "Alvaro Trevino pulls a canoe with Jennifer Tellez and Ailyn, 8, after they checked on their home on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Spendora, Texas. The family has lived on the property in a rental trailer for two years. \"It's really bad,\" said Tellez, who says they stayed dry during the most recent flooding in February. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were stranded on rooftops.\n\nA 5-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\n___\n\nBy JAMIE STENGLE and LEKAN OYEKANMI Associated Press\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. {"uri": "2024-05-345872364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "19:51:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T19:51:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T19:49:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://cw39.com/news/local/more-storms-move-through-houston-area-where-hundreds-have-been-rescued-from-floodwaters/", "title": "More storms move through Houston area, where hundreds have been rescued from floodwaters", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- More storms were moving through the already saturated Houston area on Sunday, where flooding from heavy rains has led to the rescue of hundreds of people from homes, rooftops and roads.\n\n\"It's going to be raining through the day and some of the storms could be producing the heavier downpours,\" said National Weather Service meteorologist Hayley Adams.\n\nOver the last week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, have gotten upwards of 20 inches (50 centimeters) of rain, she said, while there has been as much as 12 inches (30 centimeters) of rain in that period in areas of northeastern Harris County, the nation's third-largest county that includes Houston.\n\nAdams said the storms coming through Sunday were expected to bring up to 3 inches of rainfall, with up to 8 inches possible in some areas.\n\n\"It's going to keep rising this way,\" said Miguel Flores Jr., who lives in the northeast Houston neighborhood of Kingwood. \"We don't know how much more. We're just preparing for the worst.\"\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries as a wide region from Houston to rural East Texas has been swamped.\n\nFLOODING FORCES EVACUATIONS\n\nMost weekends Flores' father, Miguel Flores Sr., is mowing his huge backyard on a 2.5-acre (1-hectare) lot behind his home in Kingwood. But on Saturday, he and his family loaded several vehicles with clothes, small appliances and other items.\n\nWater from the San Jacinto River already had swallowed his backyard and was continuing to rise, from about 1 foot (30 centimeters) high in the yard Friday to about 4 feet (1.2 meters) the following day.\n\nAs storms forced numerous high-water rescues, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes, officials redoubled urgent instructions for residents in low-lying areas to evacuate, warning the worst was still to come.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stood late Saturday afternoon by a golf cart as he eyed the several feet of water covering the road that leads to his home in Channelview, a community in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River.\n\nMoss had managed to pack up many of his belongings and leave before the road flooded Saturday.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nHe moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he will stay until the waters recede. Moss said he is not worried his home will flood because it's located on higher ground.\n\nWHAT'S EXPECTED NEXT\n\nRain in the area is expected to taper off by evening, said Adams, the National Weather Service meteorologist. But next up, residents recovering from the floods will have the heat and humidity to contend with.\n\nWith a combination of the lingering moisture from the rains and temperatures upwards of 90 F (32 C), the area may be looking at heat index values in the triple digits this week, she said.\n\n\"We want people to be mindful of the increasing temperatures, and heat exhaustion, heat stress,\" she Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood.\n\nPartially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.Areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. All the three counties are in or around the Houston metro area.\n\nThe water rose nearly as high as the power lines close to the East Fork of the San Jacinto. Other areas had water up to rooftops, the Houston Chronocle reported on Saturday. Hidalgo described the flooding along the East Fork as the \"worst one since Harvey.\"\n\nHidalgo on Thursday ordered a mandatory evacuation of the Houston areas along the east fork of the San Jacinto River, asking residents to leave their homes as soon as possible.\n\nHouston city officials said on Satuday that the area received about four months' worth of rain in about one week. Others prepared to evacuate their properties.\n\nA flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas.\n\n\"A lull in heavy rain is expected through (Saturday) evening,\" the National Weather Service reported. \"The next round of heavy rainfall is expected late (Saturday) into Sunday.\"\n\nUp to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas.\n\nHouston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county.\n\nA wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. {"uri": "8112554012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:14:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/texas-houston-severe-weather-forecast-millions-under-flood-watch-heavy-rain/", "title": "Millions still under flood watch as southeastern Texas braces for more rain", "body": "A flood watch remained in effect for parts of southeastern Texas on Sunday, with forecasters expecting several more inches of rainfall and potentially serious runoff across a huge area that altogether covers more than 100 square miles and includes the city of Houston. The densely populated metro center is home to more than 2 million people and has been swamped by consistently heavy downpours. Crews carried out hundreds of water rescues in Houston and the surrounding neighborhoods earlier in the weekend.\n\nFlood watches are issued when a mixture of weather hazards creates favorable conditions for flooding, but they do not necessarily mean that flooding is imminent in a particular region. A flood watch currently in effect from Harris County -- which includes Houston all the way to College Station -- was set to remain in place through Sunday evening. It also extended eastward from greater Houston toward the Gulf Coast.\n\nMeteorologists warned people within the flood watch boundaries to prepare for additional spells of rainfall and thunderstorms overnight Saturday and throughout the day on Sunday, after previous rounds of heavy rain drenched the area and submerged a wide section of land in murky high waters.\n\nCrews had already rescued more than 400 people from homes, rooftops, and roadways by Saturday as neighborhoods flooded around Houston, the Associated Press reported, while others prepared to evacuate. Judge Lina Hidalgo, the top official in Harris County where Houston is located, said at the time that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued in that jurisdiction alone. No deaths or injuries tied to the severe weather have been reported in Houston.\n\nPeople still under flood watches in southeastern Texas were bracing for between 1 and 3 inches of additional rainfall on Sunday, although the National Weather Service said higher amounts -- possibly as much as 8 inches -- could end up happening in some places.\n\nOngoing flooding along the San Jacinto River was a main cause for concern as rain caused its water levels to rise past capacity. Houston Police shared a video on social media that showed an officer rescuing a man and three dogs who were trapped in 8 to 10 feet of floodwater on Saturday morning. That rescue happened in a trailer park along a section of the San Jacinto River near Lake Houston, police said.\n\n\"Excessive runoff has resulted in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations, particularly urban areas,\" the National Weather Service said in its latest advisory, noting that river flooding continued Sunday morning and ranged from moderate to major depending on the location.\n\nA severe weather outlook issued for the same region noted that localized flash flooding was also expected, \"especially for areas that already received heavy rainfall over the last few days.\" With that, powerful and potentially damaging winds, large hail and tornadoes could also occur, according to the weather service. The heaviest rainfall was forecast in the morning.\n\nSoutheastern Texas has been hit hard by heavy rains over the last week, with Houston and neighborhoods in its vicinity feeling the brunt of the impacts. Hidalgo on Thursday announced that she had signed a disaster declaration for Harris County after the area got more rain than expected the previous night, putting communities near the San Jacinto River at particular risk, CBS affiliate KHOU reported. But storms have for days imperiled people living in river basins much farther inland, and the disaster declaration for Harris County came on the same day Texas Governor Greg Abbott expanded a broader disaster declaration to include 88 of the state's counties in total.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8113148926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:54:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:54:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13386203/Heavy-rains-ease-Houston-flooding-remains-hundreds-rescues-evacuations.html", "title": "Heavy rains ease around Houston but flooding remains after hundreds...", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) - Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were standed on rooftops.\n\nA 5-year-old boy died after riding in a car that was swept away in fast waters, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAlvaro Trevino pulls a canoe with Jennifer Tellez and Ailyn, 8, after they checked on their home on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Spendora, Texas. The family has lived on the property in a rental trailer for two years. \"It's really bad,\" said Tellez, who says they stayed dry during the most recent flooding in February. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor\u00b4s home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn\u00b4t worried his home would flood because it\u00b4s located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press\u00b4 climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. (Kirk Sides/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA mailbox is partially submerged on a flooded street in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Sunday morning, May 5, 2024. The nearby San Jacinto River, overflowing due to heavy rainfall earlier this week, caused the flood waters. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nA mobile home in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Sunday morning, May 5, 2024, is surrounded by flood waters caused by the nearby San Jacinto River, which overflowed due to heavy rainfall earlier this week. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nA mobile home in an unincorporated area in east Harris County near Houston on Sunday morning, May 5, 2024, is surrounded by flood waters caused by the nearby San Jacinto River, which overflowed due to heavy rainfall earlier this week. (AP Photo/Lekan Oyekanmi)\n\nDorothy Blevins dries out photos from her home after it was flooded by the East Branch San Jacinto River on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Spendora, Texas. \"These mean the most to me, everything else can be replaced,\" she said. Two weeks ago, her husband, Earl, closed their storage rental and put everything in their new home. \"The timing of this is terrible,\" he said. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nClouds amass over power lines follow days of storms on Sunday, May 5, 2024, in Humble, Texas. {"uri": "2024-05-345774705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:55:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:55:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T16:10:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.aol.com/millions-still-under-flood-watch-161059737.html", "title": "Millions still under flood watch as southeastern Texas braces for more rain", "body": "Millions still under flood watch as southeastern Texas braces for more rainEmily Mae CzachorMay 5, 2024 at 11:10 AM\n\nA flood watch remained in effect for parts of southeastern Texas on Sunday, with forecasters expecting several more inches of rainfall and potentially serious runoff across a huge area that altogether covers more than 100 square miles and includes the city of Houston. The densely populated metro center is home to more than 2 million people and has been swamped by consistently heavy downpours. Crews carried out hundreds of water rescues in Houston and the surrounding neighborhoods earlier in the weekend.\n\nFlood watches are issued when a mixture of weather hazards creates favorable conditions for flooding, but they do not necessarily mean that flooding is imminent in a particular region. A flood watch currently in effect from Harris County -- which includes Houston all the way to College Station -- was set to remain in place through Sunday evening. It also extended eastward from greater Houston toward the Gulf Coast.\n\nMeteorologists warned people within the flood watch boundaries to prepare for additional spells of rainfall and thunderstorms overnight Saturday and throughout the day on Sunday, after previous rounds of heavy rain drenched the area and submerged a wide section of land in murky high waters.\n\nCrews had already rescued more than 400 people from homes, rooftops, and roadways by Saturday as neighborhoods flooded around Houston, the Associated Press reported, while others prepared to evacuate. Judge Lina Hidalgo, the top official in Harris County where Houston is located, said at the time that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued in that jurisdiction alone. No deaths or injuries tied to the severe weather have been reported in Houston.\n\nPeople still under flood watches in southeastern Texas were bracing for between 1 and 3 inches of additional rainfall on Sunday, although the National Weather Service said higher amounts -- possibly as much as 8 inches -- could end up happening in some places.\n\nOngoing flooding along the San Jacinto River was a main cause for concern as rain caused its water levels to rise past capacity. Houston Police shared a video on social media that showed an officer rescuing a man and three dogs who were trapped in 8 to 10 feet of floodwater on Saturday morning. That rescue happened in a trailer park along a section of the San Jacinto River near Lake Houston, police said.\n\n\"Excessive runoff has resulted in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations, particularly urban areas,\" the National Weather Service said in its latest advisory, noting that river flooding continued Sunday morning and ranged from moderate to major depending on the location.\n\nA severe weather outlook issued for the same region noted that localized flash flooding was also expected, \"especially for areas that already received heavy rainfall over the last few days.\" With that, powerful and potentially damaging winds, large hail and tornadoes could also occur, according to the weather service. The heaviest rainfall was forecast in the morning.\n\nSoutheastern Texas has been hit hard by heavy rains over the last week, with Houston and neighborhoods in its vicinity feeling the brunt of the impacts. Hidalgo on Thursday announced that she had signed a disaster declaration for Harris County after the area got more rain than expected the previous night, putting communities near the San Jacinto River at particular risk, CBS affiliate KHOU reported. But storms have for days imperiled people living in river basins much farther inland, and the disaster declaration for Harris County came on the same day Texas Governor Greg Abbott expanded a broader disaster declaration to include 88 of the state's counties in total.\n\nLongtime Trump aide Hope Hicks takes the stand in New York trial\n\nLouisiana boy receives surprising reward after generously giving away his only dollar\n\nTexas family describes harrowing escape from devastating tornado", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112938812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "00:20:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T00:20:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T00:19:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.gulfnews.ca/a-boy-has-died-in-the-texas-floods-with-authorities-conducting-more-than-200-rescue-operations-across-the-state/", "title": "A boy has died in the Texas floods, with authorities conducting more than 200 rescue operations across the state", "body": "CNN\n\n--\n\nOn Sunday, the body of a boy was recovered from floodwaters near Fort Worth, Texas, as statewide search and rescue teams continued to patrol streets and neighborhoods flooded by rain.\n\nThe death was the first since the storms triggered disaster declarations for a third of the state's counties.\n\nJohnson County Emergency Management Coordinator Jamie Moore said the boy was found dead after authorities responded overnight to a vehicle stuck in fast-moving water. According to Moore, three residents escaped, but a 911 caller said they were swept away by floodwaters as they tried to get to safer ground.\n\nMoore, who was involved in the search, said a man and a woman were rescued.\n\n\"I hope you keep this family in your prayers,\" Moore told CNN.\n\nSeveral days of rain have left rivers in the south overflowing Homes and businesses were flooded And thousands of people were displaced.\n\nAt least 224 people were rescued from homes and vehicles in Harris County, an official said Saturday night, with evacuation orders and flood watches in place as the state was already hit by heavy rains Sunday. Houston area flooded. No deaths or serious injuries were reported in the area, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo told CNN, adding that 153 pets were rescued during the flooding.\n\n\"It's very sad to see the impact on people's livelihoods, homes, infrastructure and public infrastructure,\" Hidalgo told CNN on Saturday.\n\n\"We're actually asking everyone to give it a minute before they go home.\"\n\nAgain Oyekanmi/AP\n\nTexas Parks and Wildlife Department officials used boats to rescue residents from flooding.\n\nSee also Two friends stayed in the pool for hours before escaping the Maui wildfires\n\nCNN's Rosa Flores rode a boat Sunday with rescuers from the Harris County Sheriff's Office and said the craft went over fences and mailboxes. Stop signs were at eye level.\n\nIn some areas, the water receded on Sunday, but was still high.\n\nFirst responders took CNN to an area where the banks of the San Jacinto River were unknown.\n\n\"It's very difficult to tell where the river ends,\" Lt. David Jasper said.\n\nBrent Taylor, chief communications officer for the Houston Office of Emergency Management, told CNN's Amara Walker that many people in Houston were evacuated ahead of the severe weather.\n\n\"We have Houston police and Houston firefighters who are patrolling these neighborhoods near the river, and the water has gotten really high,\" Taylor said. \"Hey, I'm stuck here!\" There are times when someone screams for help.\"\n\n\"We have high water rescue vehicles. We have jet skis, we have airboats. Our Houston Department of Public Works has dump trucks loaded to move people through those high waters, so it's really a coordinated effort to make sure these Houstonians are safe,\" he added.\n\nNot everyone wanted to leave their homes, Harris County Sheriff's Office Deputy Darrell Bailey told CNN's crew as they rode by.\n\n\"They have a lot of people in that area who don't want to leave because they don't have a place to go and they don't want to go to a shelter,\" he said.\n\nNational Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration website West Gulf River Forecast Center Eight river gauges in Texas are in major flood stage, 21 are in moderate flood stage, and 38 are in minor flood stage.\n\nSee also Tom Verlaine, Singer and TV Guitarist, Dies at 73 - Rolling Stone\n\nMost of the weekend's rain fell in West and Central Texas, but the Houston area is expected to receive more heavy rain on Sunday.\n\nNational Weather Service office in Houston Published in X At 1:30 pm CT, \"The next round of storms has arrived and continues to train along the I-10 corridor.\"\n\nJackson, Wharton and Colorado counties were under one Severe Thunderstorm Watch Storm activity is expected to subside by 7pm today.\n\nEarlier, the office said 1 to 3 inches of rain could fall through Monday morning. Some areas could see 4 to 8 inches.\n\n\"Several rounds of heavy rain over the past week may result in earlier flooding than expected under normal conditions. Today's rain will further increase existing river flooding,\" the Houston Weather Service office warned.\n\nRainfall has been high in the region over the past week, with some areas receiving two months' worth of rain in five days. The weather service lists some of the rain totals it collected:\n\nGroveton, TX- 23.56\" Huntsville, TX- 21.76\" Splendora, TX- 21.01\" Willis, TX- 20.75\" Livingston, TX- 18.42\"\n\nHowever, there is relief on the horizon. The forecast for the rest of the week in Houston calls for dry weather and warm temperatures Monday through Saturday, with plenty of sunshine helping the region dry out.\n\nThis week's storms are the latest in a string of brutal weather events to hit the state since early April. Dozens of hurricanes have struck from the Panhandle to the Gulf Coast, softball-sized hail in parts of the state and months of rain in East Texas that have raised rivers to levels not seen since the disaster. flood Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\n\nSee also Packers president says Aaron Rodgers return top option\n\nJason Vogtman/Houston Chronicle/AP\n\nThe bridge over Lake Houston on the West Lake Houston Parkway from Kingwood to Atascocita is closed due to high water Saturday in Kingwood, Texas.\n\nThere are mandatory evacuations in the Houston area and surrounding counties as local officials compare it to past disasters. The flooding was \"85% worse than Hurricane Harvey,\" Emmitt Eldridge, emergency management coordinator for San Jacinto County, told CNN. \"This is a historic flood for Walker County. We've had more flooding from this event than we did during Hurricane Harvey,\" said Sherry Bekoda, Walker County's deputy emergency management coordinator.\n\nA mandatory evacuation order remains in effect for low-lying areas of Polk County through Sunday evening, emergency managers said in a statement. Others prepared to evacuate their properties. A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night and the likelihood of major flooding in Harris County, the nation's third-largest county which includes Houston, and nearby areas. Up to 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of additional rain was expected, with up to 5 inches (12.7 centimeters) possible in isolated areas. Houston authorities have not reported any deaths or injuries. Judge Lina Hidalgo, Harris County's top elected official, said Saturday that 178 people and 122 pets had been rescued so far in the county. A wide region has been swamped from Houston to rural East Texas, where game wardens rode airboats through waist-high waters rescuing people and pets who did not evacuate in time. The San Jacinto River crested on Saturday, he said.\n\nSo far, Sunday's additional rain did not seem to be causing any new flooding but he urged people to still be cautious, noting that many areas were still flooded.\n\n\"We really need everybody to give it just another day before we feel comfortable that conditions are safe,\" Mr Lindner said.\n\nIn the past week, areas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches of rain, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said on Sunday.\n\nScattered showers in the Houston area on Sunday brought light to moderate rainfall, he said. He said the rain would taper off in the evening, with no heavy rain events expected in the next week or so.\n\nStorms brought as nine inches of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area overnight, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley. He said the rains washed out some roads west of Waco.\n\nIn Brazil, floods in southern Rio Grande do Sul state had killed at least 75 people in the past seven days, and another 103 were reported missing, local authorities said on Sunday.\n\nAt least 155 people were injured, while damage from the rains forced more than 88,000 people from their homes. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview cancelled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,'' Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighbourhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 cm) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 5-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 am Sunday, an official said.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 am and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 am in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 cm) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\" Moss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\n(This story has not been edited by {"uri": "8113029068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:36:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:36:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:36:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ksltv.com/641933/young-boy-dies-in-texas-floodwaters-as-authorities-make-more-than-200-rescues-across-state/", "title": "Young boy dies in Texas floodwaters as authorities make more than 200 rescues across state", "body": "(CNN) -- The body of a young boy was recovered from floodwaters near Fort Worth, Texas, on Sunday, as search and rescue teams statewide continue to patrol streets and neighborhoods inundated by rainfall.\n\nThe death is the first reported fatality following storms that have prompted disaster declarations for over a third of the state's counties.\n\nJohnson County Emergency Management Coordinator Jamie Moore said the deceased boy was found after authorities responded to an overnight call for a vehicle stuck in rapidly moving water. The three occupants escaped but a 911 caller said they were swept into the floodwaters when they tried to get to safe ground, according to Moore.\n\nA man and woman were rescued, said Moore, who was involved in the search.\n\n\"I hope you will keep this family in your prayers,\" Moore told CNN.\n\nWith days of rain, rivers farther south have swollen, leaving homes and businesses flooded and thousands of people displaced.\n\nAt least 224 people have been rescued from homes and vehicles in Harris County, an official said Saturday night, with evacuation orders and flood watches in place, as more rain descended on the state Sunday, with a bull's-eye of excessive rainfall over the already waterlogged Houston area. No deaths or serious injuries had been reported in that area, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo told CNN, adding 153 pets have also been rescued during the deluge.\n\n\"It's been really sad to see the impact of people's livelihoods, homes, infrastructure as well as just the public infrastructure,\" Hidalgo told CNN on Saturday.\n\n\"We're really asking folks to give it a minute before they go back home.\"\n\nCNN's Rosa Flores rode in a boat Sunday with rescuers from the Harris County Sheriff's Office and said the craft passed over fences and mailboxes. Stop signs were at eye level.\n\nIn some areas, the water had receded Sunday but was still very high.\n\nThe first responders took CNN to an area where the banks of the San Jacinto River were not visible.\n\n\"It's kinda hard to tell where the river ends,\" Lt. David Jasper said.\n\nMany people in Houston were evacuated before the worst of the severe weather, Brent Taylor, chief communications officer for the Houston Office of Emergency Management, told CNN's Amara Walker.\n\n\"We have Houston Police and Houston Fire who are patrolling these neighborhoods that are near the river and where the water is gone so high,\" Taylor said. \"There's been some instances where it's someone just yelling for help saying, 'Hey, I'm stuck over here!'\"\n\n\"We have high water rescue vehicles. We have Jet Skis, we have air boats. Our Houston Public Works Department has dump trucks that can be outfitted to move people through those high waters, so it really is a unified effort to make sure that these Houstonians are staying safe,\" he added.\n\nNot everyone wanted to leave their homes, Deputy Darrell Bailey of the Harris County Sheriff's Office told CNN's crew on their ride-along.\n\n\"They have a lot of people in the area who don't want to leave because they'd have no place to go and they don't want to go to the shelter,\" he said.\n\nThe website for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's West Gulf River Forecast Center shows eight river gauges in Texas in major flood stage, 21 in moderate flooding and 38 in minor flooding.\n\nMost of the weekend's rain fell over western and central Texas, but there was a significant chance of heavier rain in the greater Houston area Sunday.\n\nThe National Weather Service office in Houston posted on X at 1:30 p.m. CT, the \"next round of storms has arrived and continue to train along the I-10 corridor.\"\n\nJackson, Wharton, and Colorado counties were under a severe thunderstorm watch in effect until 7 p.m. Storm activity is expected to wind down this evening.\n\nEarlier, the office said 1 to 3 more inches of rain were possible by Monday morning. Some areas could see up to 4 to 8 inches.\n\n\"Because of multiple rounds of heavy rain over the past week, flooding may be seen earlier than would be expected under typical conditions. Rainfall today will continue to exacerbate existing river flooding,\" warned the Houston weather service office.\n\nThe rainfall amounts in the region have been huge over the past week, with some areas picking up two months worth of rain in five days. The weather service listed some of the rainfall totals it collected:\n\nThere is relief on the horizon, however. The rest of the week's forecast for Houston is showing dry weather and warm temperatures from Monday through Saturday, with lots of sunshine to help dry the region out.\n\nThis week's storms were just the latest in a series of brutal weather events that have pounded the state since early April. Dozens of tornadoes have hit from the Panhandle to the Gulf Coast, some areas of the state have been pounded with softball-sized hail and months of rain has fallen in East Texas in intense spurts, causing rivers to rise to levels not seen since the devastating floods of Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\n\nMandatory evacuations are in place in counties in and around the Houston area, as local officials make comparisons to past disasters. The flooding is \"85% worse than Hurricane Harvey,\" Emmitt Eldridge, San Jacinto County's emergency management coordinator, told CNN. \"This has been a historic flood for Walker County. We have flooded more from this event than we did during Hurricane Harvey,\" Sherri Pegoda, Walker County's deputy emergency management coordinator, said.\n\nA mandatory evacuation order remains in place for low-lying unincorporated areas of Polk County through Sunday evening, emergency managers said in a Facebook post, as are homes along rivers in Harris and Montgomery counties.\n\nDisaster declarations are active for over a third of Texas counties after Gov. Greg Abbott expanded the storm-related declarations in response to the flooding, according to a news release. Additional counties could be added in the coming days, particularly with more storms in the forecast.", "source": {"uri": "ksltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSLTV.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8114172587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:59:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:59:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:57:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/news/nation/heavy-rains-ease-around-houston-but-flooding-remains-after-hundreds-of-rescues-and-evacuations/article_67cb4f04-7b05-553f-a4e7-bd6b560e7b9d.html", "title": "Heavy rains ease around Houston but flooding remains after hundreds of rescues and evacuations", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Floodwaters closed some Texas schools on Monday after days of heavy rains pummeled the Houston area and led to hundreds of rescues including people who were stranded on rooftops.\n\nA 4-year-old boy died fter being swept away in fast waters after the car he was riding in got stuck, authorities said.\n\nAlthough forecasters expected storms to begin tapering off in southeastern Texas, high waters continued to close some roads and left residents facing lengthy cleanups in neighborhoods where rising river levels led to weekend evacuation orders.\n\nHouston is one of the most flood-prone metro areas in the country. Hurricane Harvey in 2017 dumped historic rainfall that flooded thousands of homes and resulted in more than 60,000 rescues.\n\nIn one soggy area of Houston, school officials in Channelview canceled classes and said a survey of their employees found many of them had experienced circumstances that would prevent them from coming to work.\n\n\"These folks have suffered much, people,\" Trinity County Sheriff Woody Wallace said Sunday during a Facebook livestream as he rode a boat through a rural flooded neighborhood. Partially submerged cars and street signs peeked above the water around him.\n\nAreas near Lake Livingston, located northeast of Houston, received upwards of 23 inches (58 centimeters) of rain over the past week, National Weather Service meteorologist Jimmy Fowler said.\n\nIn Johnson County, south of Fort Worth, a 4-year-old boy died when he was swept away after the vehicle he was riding in became stuck in swift-moving water near the community of Lillian just before 2 a.m. Sunday, an official said. The Tarrant County medical examiner's office said the cause of death of the child, who would have turned 5 later this month, was drowning.\n\nThe child and two adults were trying to reach dry ground when they were swept away. The adults were rescued around 5 a.m. and taken to a hospital, while the child was found dead around 7:20 a.m. in the water, Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore wrote in a social media post.\n\nStorms brought 9 inches (23 centimeters) of rain in a span of six to eight hours in some areas from central Texas to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, National Weather Service meteorologist Matt Stalley said.\n\nToday's Top Headlines Rolls-Royce adding capacity at Graniteville plant to meet data center backup power demands Super fun: Kentucky Derby parties provide boost for charities Jackson resident finds purpose, fulfillment as foster parent Business roundup: New Japanese restaurant opens, La Parisienne has new co-owner Today's events for May 6 MEDICAL INSIGHTS: Limit your consumption of ultra processed foods 2 men arrested in connection with shooting near Hitchcock Animal Hospital Shakes and shouts: Greenville, Dorman's Ruth win titles on tense final day at Southern Cross Beautification and preservation: Garden Club of Aiken celebrates a century USC Aiken Eventing teams finish in top 10 at USEA Intercollegiate Championship, reflect on growth of club\n\nSince last week, storms have forced numerous high-water rescues in the Houston area, including some from the rooftops of flooded homes.\n\nGreg Moss, 68, stayed put in his recreational vehicle on Sunday after leaving his home in the community of Channelview in eastern Harris County near the San Jacinto River. A day earlier, he had packed up many of his belongings and left before the road to his home flooded.\n\n\"I would be stuck for four days,\" Moss said. \"So now at least I can go get something to eat.\"\n\nMoss moved his belongings and vehicle to a neighbor's home, where he planned to stay until the waters recede. The floodwaters had already gone down by a couple of feet and he wasn't worried his home would flood because it's located on higher ground, Moss said Sunday.\n\nThis story corrects the age of the young boy who died to 4 instead of 5.\n\nStengle reported from Dallas and Associated Press reporter Juan A. Lozano contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-345771464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "16:50:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T16:50:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:56:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/least-224-people-153-pets-131835441.html", "title": "At least 224 people, 153 pets rescued in Texas floods with more rain in the forecast", "body": "As rivers swell across South Texas, leaving homes and businesses flooded and thousands of people displaced, residents are looking skyward Sunday as the threat of more rain looms.\n\nAt least 224 people have been rescued from homes and vehicles in Harris County, Texas, an official said Saturday night, with evacuation orders and flood watches in place, as more rain expected descends on the state Sunday, with a bull's-eye of excessive rainfall over the already waterlogged Houston area.\n\nNo deaths or serious injuries have been reported, Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo told CNN, adding 153 pets have also been rescued during the deluge.\n\n\"It's been really sad to see the impact of people's livelihoods, homes, infrastructure as well as just the public infrastructure,\" Hidalgo told CNN Saturday.\n\n\"We're really asking folks to give it a minute before they go back home.\"\n\nMany people in the City of Houston were evacuated before the worst of the severe weather, Brent Taylor, chief communications officer for the Houston Office of Emergency Management told CNN's Amara Walker Sunday.\n\n\"We have Houston Police and Houston Fire who are patrolling these neighborhoods that are near the river and where the water is gone so high,\" Taylor said. \"There's been some instances where it's someone just yelling for help saying, 'Hey, I'm stuck over here!'\"\n\n\"We have high water rescue vehicles. We have Jet Skis, we have air boats. Our Houston Public Works Department has dump trucks that can be outfitted to move people through those high waters, so it really is a unified effort to make sure that these Houstonians are staying safe,\" he added.\n\nForecast calls for rain Sunday into Monday\n\nMost of the weekend's rain fell over western and central Texas, but there's a significant chance of heavier rain in the greater Houston area Sunday.\n\nAn additional 1 to 3 inches of rainfall possible by Monday morning, according to the Houston National Weather Service office. Isolated areas could see up to 4 to 8 inches of rainfall.\n\n\"Because of multiple rounds of heavy rain over the past week, flooding may be seen earlier than would be expected under typical conditions. Rainfall today will continue to exacerbate existing river flooding,\" warned the Houston weather service office.\n\nThe rainfall amounts in the region have been huge over the past week, with some areas picking up two months worth of rain in five days. The weather service listed some of the rainfall totals it collected:\n\nThere is relief on the horizon, however. The rest of the week's forecast for Houston is showing dry weather and warm temperatures from Monday through Saturday, with lots of sunshine to help dry the region out.\n\nThis week's storms were just the latest in a series of brutal weather events that have pounded the state since early April. Dozens of tornadoes have hit from the Panhandle to the Gulf Coast, some areas of the state have been pounded with softball-sized hail and months of rain has fallen in East Texas in intense spurts, causing rivers to rise to levels not seen since the devastating floods of Hurricane Harvey in 2017.\n\nMandatory evacuations are in place in counties in and around the Houston area, as local officials make comparisons to past disasters. The flooding is \"85% worse than Hurricane Harvey,\" Emmitt Eldridge, San Jacinto County's emergency management coordinator, told CNN. \"This has been a historic flood for Walker County. We have flooded more from this event than we did during Hurricane Harvey,\" Sherri Pegoda, Walker County's deputy emergency management coordinator, said.\n\nA mandatory evacuation order remains in place for low-lying unincorporated areas of Polk County through Sunday evening, emergency managers said in a Facebook post, as are homes along rivers in Harris and Montgomery counties.\n\nDisaster declarations are active for over a third of Texas counties after Gov. Greg Abbott expanded the storm-related declarations in response to the flooding, according to a news release. Additional counties could be added in the coming days, particularly with more storms in the forecast.\n\nCNN's Allison Chinchar, Ray Sanchez, Andy Rose and Chris Boyette contributed to this report.",
